list.item: Mark Ward —young fellow in fort Greene—talk from 10 to 12—May 23d '62
John Sweeten —tall, well tann'd, and born in New Jersey—drives 40. 4th av. May 27 '62—was a boy in Philadelphia riots of '44 Aug 19 drives 23 4

Dan'l Spencer Spencer, pere, 214 44th st. & 59 William somewhat feminine—5th av (44 ) 49) (May 29th)—told me he had never been in a fight and did not drink at all Sept 3 deserted, returned to N.Y. gone in 2d N.Y. light artillery
Dr Hogan, drug store, in Center street east side just west south of Leonard.—
Thos Gray good looking young Scotchman elegantly dress'd—does the tricks cutting his finger &c—at Pfaff's and Raffeley's May, June, July 1862

damned shyster Dr. Wm. Lamont Wheeler , surgeon U.S.N.—met at Pfaff's, June '62, with Charles Kingsley—

Wm Miller 8th st (has powder slightly in his face.)
Harry , (the old fellow, starter, Madison av & 40th street

William Mead , 36 or 7—on Fort Greene Sunday evening July 6th '62 Said he was at Huntington in 1838, when I printed the Long Islander there—is now a book‑canvasser; for Thomas Pelham, Hamp's brother—thinks there must be 60000 Peterson's & Godey's magazines taken in New York city—talked about canvassing—Huntington &c—Ezra Brown—Bradford Platt &c
Dick Sullivan —No 1—8th st & Broadway May—June—July—'62

Aaron B. Bell , (of Lyme, Connecticut) who thought deeply about Leaves of Grass, and wished to see me.
George Marler (April 29—driving No 8. large‑nosed, tallish fellow—Western on 4th av. Is from Ohio—has traveled with a show as "candy butcher"
James Willis , (tall, talks sort of spasmodically April 29—driving No 1 & 4th av—is a carman or truckman—first appearance as a driver)
Phineas (on 23d st 37—is from New Jersey—brown faced,
William Mead —(April, drives 25 4th av. quiet, and serious looking.) July 4, gone to Newbern

Victor Smith (Evening June 30 '62 Met a man who introduced himself to me as Victor Smith —in the met him in Washington is a light house agent Pugets Sound government employ on the Pacific coast northern Oregon, as collector &c there—he and wife thought very much of L. of G.—said it had made a disturbance between her and her sisters, &c. Said that Mr. Chase (Secretary of Treasury) one evening, seeing the book on the centre table, said, "How is it possible you can have this nasty book here?"—&c &c
Elijah Tompkins June '62 1304 Broadway 17 joined 2d NY artillery Deserted arrested in Brooklyn

Henry Kelly , July 7th '62 Madison avenue, about 24, born in Lawrence, Mass. father Irish, mother English, has worked about the Lawrence factories—had a brother or sister in Pemberton Mill, when it fell——has travel'd some time in south and west with Dan Rise's show—florid face—manner fresh and direct—(I notice a few gray hairs)—seems to be inclined to join the army—rode all the way to Wall st and back to Howard July 10 talk about the mishaps &c of a showman's life south and north
Charles Winthrop Morse (45 5th av) July, '62—Yankee, says he has a farm, and is working to get money for it &c
James L. Metcalf , is appointed in the 5th precinct, July 7th '62

Pell , young man, American, introduced by Chas. Kingsley, at 6th st. lager bier house, night July 8th '62
Isaac Bennett deck hand, ferry, square build, young fellow, black moustache & imperial—July 10, '62
John Wattles —young man on ferry boat goes to Baily Velsors in N.J.

list.item: William Cochran, (July 11th) 5th av. is aged 30, was born in Nova Scotia, lived there til 16—went to Boston, was clerk &c—made some money—married—went back to Nova Scotia—went into business—lost all—has a family of wife & two children—middling sized—clean shaved (Aug '64 is sup't coaches at Astor House)
John Myers, (Whitey) July 12 '62 6th av.—white hair and complexion—brother of Dan Myers,—John tells me he has been very sick with measles &c—
Campbell McEwen, (July 18, '62) fireman Fulton ferry—scotch by birth
Mark Graynor , Sunday night, July 20. on Fort Greene young, 5 ft 7 in. black moustache, plumber,—has lived west—travel'd West Indies, &c

Hazard—(or Hazell,)—Yankee, with full beard, very smart—quite a great traveler—especially west and south, and in the West Indies—has had much to do in railroad building—south & in Cuba &c—says that white men can labor be as well as blacks, or better, in the tropics

Omnibuses were first introduced in Paris in 1825—and gradually into other cities of Europe—and into Great Britain and America

work.p: Charles Glicksberg suggests the possibility that this description of William Giggee's death may be the germinal idea of " Vigil Strange I Kept on the Field One Night which first appeared in 1865 within Drum-Taps ( Walt Whitman and the Civil War , [Philadelphia: University of Pennsylvania Press, 1933], 142). The poem appears under the same title within the "Drum-Taps" cluster of the "deathbed" edition of Leaves of Grass ( 1892 ). [1865: "Vigil Strange I Kept on the Field One Night" ( Drum-Taps ). 1867: (early copies of this edition include unbound copies of Drum-Taps ). 1871:("Drum-Taps" cluster)].

William Robinson, joined 2d NY artillery— Brooklyn lad, (socratic nose) Aug 16—driving on 23d st—is going to enlist—said he would enlist with me in two minutes—& has enlisted in 2d NY artillery

Joseph Perry. (Aug 19 '62) No. 11, 23d st. 21 yrs old—thinnish, rather tallish—always cheerful and laughing—father killed by accident coupling railroad cars—has three younger brothers & mother

William Talbot —harsh‑faced—friend of Eric—Sept 17 '62—14th st—told me of Eric's death—

Joseph Cornell , 15, 7th av (306)—smallish, married, friend of Eric's—(the night, Sept 18th '62, I rode down and up with him, and we talked of Eric's death—I left him at on Amity st.)

William Giggee , Sept. 18th '62 , I heard of poor Bill's death—he was shot on Pope's retreat—Arthur took him in his arms, and he died in about an hour and a half—Arthur buried him himself he dug his grave

div2.p:
you go to
bureause bureaux des omnibus
—a man there gives you a numbered check, entitling you to the seat of that number
you don't pay for the tickets, when you buy them—you pay the driver
perfect system of transfer, so that you pass anywhere over Paris.
all the omnibusses in Paris are owned by one grand company
routes are as long as ours—

woman for Jeff. has been away 3 mos. with the 47th in Baltimore, American stock—tall and slender

l.seg: I greet with love, each field and grove,
And thou, blue, billowy sea I love,
Life giving light, no depth & height,
Thou, heavenly Sun, art my delight.
But more than all the Earth's fair array,
More than the blue waves dancing play,
Love I
The dawning light of heavenly rest,
Within a trembling human breast.

work.p: These notes refer to the poem " The City Dead-House " which first appeared in the 1867 edition of Leaves of Grass . The poem appears under the same title in the "Autumn Rivulets" cluster within the "deathbed" edition of Leaves of Grass ( 1892 ). [1867: "The City Dead-House." 1882:("Autumn Rivulets" cluster).]
This is a draft version of " The City Dead-House " probably reworked from the erased notes on the previous page.

div2.p: (That is the house— I mean not the brick mortar, and brick and wood)

l.seg: a poor wrecked dead prostitute—
her body house
The Dead House

Not the there rising from by
the accepted
the capital
But the pox wrack'd corpse,
after spasms
The drunken dead wretch borne on a stretcher —the
divine woman, born there lying so still,

lying there
dead
cold and decaying there
That The house of the divine woman dead,—dead—long

dead,—
joyous
erewhile and laughing,
but long long dead.

Th
in about
Echoing Months,
years, that an echoing garnished
house—but O dead, dead,
dead dead
— Now all is over— but the occupant
Not the low brick house where I walk just aside
from the Hospital

But the poor
wreck'd corpse,
lying there in the open after spasms
The drunken wretch prostitute dead, dead
borne in on a stretcher
The divine woman, lying so still,
cold and decaying there,
(That is the house I mean — not
the other of mortar, brick,
and wood.)
The house of the woman dead— dead
joyous talking, erewhile, and laughing—
but long dead, for
Months, years, an echoing, garnish'd
house—but dead, dead,
dead.

outrageous conduct of policeman—pulling the driver down from his stage, tearing the clothes off his back—and then going up to the stables, and taking him off to the station house, and locking him up all night—Brought before Justice Connolly next morning, he was discharged, even on the policeman's own statement.

The Most of the Broadway squad of policeman are very well behaved to drivers, (although there are exceptions.) But new police suddenly occasionally detailed for some special ly occasion to Broadway are apt to be very insolent and unreasonable

div2.p: Suppositions theory as of one who saw where the existing condition of literature was weak, and needed strengthening—what was most needed in America and through a long range of the future—
How the great organizations of machinery, education, refinement, peace, and general domestic social security, make civili men now, (and current literature) deficient in those strong fibres that

There are in things two elements, fused though antagonistic: One is that bodily element, which has in itself the pr quality of corruption and decease; the other is the element, the Soul, which ever g goes on, in I think, in unknown ways, enduring for ever and ever

p.note: Fatigued by their journey they sat down on Nature's divan whence they regarded the sky. Pressing one another's hands, shoulder to shoulder neither knowing why, both became oppressed, their mouths opened, without uttering a word they kissed one another. Near them the hyacinth & the violet marrying their perfume. on raising their heads they both saw God who smiled at them from his azure balcony: Love one another he said he it is for that I have clothed your path with velvet; kiss one another, I am not looking. Love one another; love one another & if you are happy, instead of a prayer to thank me kiss again.

The poem appears under the same title within the "Drum-Taps" cluster of the "deathbed" edition of Leaves of Grass ( 1892 ). [1865: "By the Bivouac's Fitful Flame." div2.head:
Roan
O 51st N.Y. Col. Ferrero
div2.p:
Started from New York, Oct. 30 '61. —went to Annapolis and laid in the Camp of Instruction two months & six days. Sailed Jan 6th '62 in transports for Hatteras— bad terrible storm & blow, some vessels sunk,— m short of water + rations—started from Hatteras Feb. 4th up Pamlico Sound—arrived at Roanoke Feb. 6th, battle of Roanoke—bombardment of the rebel, works, water batteries, all by our gun boats, near all day on 7th, latter part of the day troops landed +
Capt. S Sims and company were first ashore, bad weather, raining and miserable weather, no fires would burn &c men lay in the wet &c morning 8th the battle commenced, —51st marched debouched through a horrible swamp to avoid a road battery. the 51st were ordered int through —the Brooklyn colors were the first planted ashore on in some of the most
difficult difficult positions, rebel force 4500 men and several batteries, some of the guns very fine. On the charge the Brooklyn boys colo were ahead with the foremost.— The rebels as is well known were def This battle was a prett loss of the 51st 4 killed, and 28 wounded

list.item: Regiments in Ferraro's Brigade

note.ab: 300 51st Pa was not in Roanoke or

item.note: the three old reg. formerly Reno's

div2.p: Stopt there in Roanoke in the barracks 6th of March—went aboard transports sailed on the 11th destination unknown—arrived at Slocum's creek. Neuse rain, on the 13th landed, formed on shore (raining like blazes) and started Newburn 16 miles distant for Newburn, passed lately-deserted barracks, earthworks, &c (Newber marched 13 miles, and bivouack'd (rain continues, bad as ever)—morning of the 14th, advanced toward started for Newbern, attack'd the rebels, protected in their breast‑works—after 4 hours fighting, the battle was won—(all this was 3 miles from Newbern)—in this affair the 51st was lost 103 kill'd and wounded, 8 of them officers—when near Newbern, found it was in flames—that night, bivouack'd outside of Newbern—

After
E e ntering Newbern, (which was not till a week or two after the above battle,) the regiment till July 5th on which date the 51st start ed s for Newport News (the 51st has lost 5 men by drowning)

landed at At Newport News July 9th and lay in good quarters, till Aug. 2d— then struck tents, and went aboard transports to Fort A Monroe—from there went up the Potomac to Aquia creek, and thence to Falmouth, opposite Fredicksburgh Fredericksburg —Aug. 12, left and arrived at march'd to Culpper station where they arrived Aug. 14th, under Gen
(under Gen Pope) —15th moved on to Cedar Run, (— there pitched into corn, sheep and vegetables)—19th made up large enough camp fires and at 1 o'clock at night moved off to Rappahanock, at Kelly's ford, cross forded the river, (under a bad rain,)—Aug 23d, left and the next day reach'd Sulpher springs,—25th at Warrenton— (all the last —Aug 29th at Bull Run, on the 30th in battle.—This is the third general engagement the 51st was in (loss 10 killed, and 50 wounded) — they were of great help in saving the artillery and baggage wagons

Sept 14th the fifth battle —the battle of South Mountain,— commenced at dusk, and lasted till nine o'clock P.M.—slept on their arms— rebel slaughter of rebels heavy—loss of the 51st 6 killed, 15 wounded—
15th marched towards Sha 16th and marched, fought, shell shot and shell from the enemy pretty heavy

div2.head: reminiscence of reminiscence of a conversation with Hollam the English historian
div2.p: "When I listened to him as the younger generation delighted to listen to a man who knew so much, and who took such care to preserve a dispassionate habit of mind, he told me that he could admit nothing that was grounded on the assumption that the human race or its work of human society was progressive. He believed it probable that there were periods of progress now and then, here and there; but it seemed plain to him that affairs recurred to their old position, and that there were men as wise and good in the most ancient as in the most modern times. Whether en masse, or in regard to the best specimens of each age, it was to him very doubtful whether we got on; and indeed he considered that the evidence tended to another conclusion."

The 51st has been in seven general engagements , and sixteen skirmishes —acquiring a reputation, (in common with the whole 2d brigade (of the 2d division of the 9th army corps) for cou endurance,
perseverance persevererance, and daring, not excelled by any in the whole army of the U.S.— in at Antietam (in taking the bridge and Fredericksburgh they did the work of old veterans.—

at the former in taking the bridge (conjointly with the 51st Pa.) the regiment performed a deed of daring hardly excelled in any where. Gen. Burnside pronounced i n t the best thing he had seen in the whole war.)

—At Fredericksburgh the regiment held an important hill, lying acting as an acting advanced picket in force, going on a 9 o'clock, on the evening of the Dec. 14th and holding it till Monday night, at 12 o'clock—they lay flat in the mud

div2.head: 17th sixth battle of Antietam
div2.p: in this battle the 51st fought the fight for the br an important bridge (see the rebellion record) between two hills—the rebels on one side—advancing on the bridge, shouting loudly &c—(loss 80 or 90 killed and wounded) order was given by Col. Potter to "charge the bridge!" The 51st did so, with a cheer, an cleared the bridge, to the end—fight lasted all day—51st were again at the end of the day ordered on further desperate service taking the bridge again —the battle was—
Seventh battle , that of Fredericksburgh

div2.head: Col. Robert B. Potter
div2.p: After the original Colonel, Ferrero, was p P romoted. Lt. Col. Potter was made became colo l nel of the regiment, acting for the first time as such at the second battle of Bull run. On inquiring I found His chief merits appeared to be are courage and coolness. When he orders the men to lie down, for protection in an engagement, he will be very likely to walk coolly up and down in front of them, observing operations all around. "Lie down yourself, Colonel," the men will cry out, "some of the rebs will see you." "Yes," he will answer, "but I want to see them too."

"healthy heart" a man who would shirk, and make something up

div2.p: —eating the green corn—grated through tin pans with rough holes pierced in them the troops had to do this repeatedly in Virginia, on Pope's retreat
"army pies" and "wha "wash," hard crackers and coffee
"western milk" i.e. whiskey (when put in your coffee

After a march in at dusk, in fifteen minutes after the men a get the order to halt, they will have their camp fires burning in all directions and the grub in process of cooking, coffee, pork, beef, potatoes boiling, chickens, or any thing they stole or grabbed in any way.

div2.head: The balloon—
div2.p:
Monday, Dec. 22—forenoon very pleasant sunshining, st a partial haze—Saw the balloon up—a great huge, slow moving thing, with a curious look to me as it crawled up, and slanted down again, as if it were alive. The haze, I suppose, prevented any good of its use—for it staid up only a little while. This balloon is
a A
beautiful object— to me, this ball great balloon— a graceful, pear‑shaped thing some 30 by 50 cubic feet, (at a guess.) I examined it, by and by, where it was grappled on the ground, in a picturesque ravine, west of Gen. Sumner's head‑quarters, lifting swelling up there in its diamond‑shaped netting, with a watchful
guard sentry over it night and day.

div2.head: The 51st at night
div2.p: My walk out around the camp, the fires burning.—groups around the —the merry song—the sitting forms—the playing light on the faces—they would tell stories

—one would tell a story of a dead man sitting on the top rail of a fence—he had been shot there, at sundown mortally wounded, clung with desperate strong nerves and was found sitting there, staring dead, staring with fixed eyes in the morning—

Then I heard of Charley Parker, a young man in Company E. in the 51st, how he was shot at Frederickburgh on the advance, died hard, suffered much frothed at the mouth—his body on the return, found entirely stript by the rebels secesh , and was decently buried by his companions. How he was a noble, beloved young man; one of the men soldiers knew his father, "a most re and how man Charley was no one n could possibly be a greater credit to his family. A clear, gallant soul, soldier lad, of the 51st; old Brooklyn

div2.head: Monday forenoon, Dec. 22
div2.p: I write this in the tent of Capt. Sims, of the 51st New York

div2.p: the at the foot of tree, immediately in front a heap of feet, legs, arms, and human fragments cut, bloody, black and blue, swelled, and sickening—in the garden near, a row of groves; some distance back, a little while afterwards, I saw a long row of them
the walk along the Rappahanock in front a pleasant shore and water, with trees,—See that old town over there—how splintered, bursted, crumbled the houses—some with their chimneys m thrown down
the hospitals—the man with his mouth blown out
the balloon

div2.head: Sunday Dec. 21st Regimental Inspection Parade, 51st N.Y.V.
div2.p: Fine, bright pleasant, bright day, bright & sunshining but cool enough to freeze; about 11 o'clock Col. Potter had an a regimental inspection, and read the articles of war. The men looked well impress to me, not in the sense of a dandy march down Broadway, parade but with the show look of men who knew had long known what real war was, and taken many a hand in—held their own in seven general engagements, and some about a score of skirmishes &c.— of a regiment that had been sifted by death, disablements, &c from eleven hundred men, (including recruits,) down to about two hundred—any one of whom had now an experience, after fifteen (eighteen months, worth more, and more wonderful, than all the romances ever written—whose story, if written out, would by a first class
Friday, Saturday, & Sunday Dec. 19, 20, and 21, was at Falmouth, opposite Fredericksburgh

The grub was good—had a tip‑top time every way—Capt. Sims, Lieut. Frank Butler, Orderly MacReady, and —all used me well—grub good—went around among the camps—saw the hard accommodations and experiences of campaign life—the shelter tents—the improvised fireplaces in holes in the ground, the chimneys with small subterranean passsages with and small mud chimneys, lengthened out with by a barrel with both ends knocked out—Went round mornings and evenings among the men—heard their conversation, &c—the bivouac fires at night, the singing and story telling, among the crowded crouching groups.—Every one speaks so well of George,—they say he is so brave, steady, his is good natured, of few words—he is now Captain

div2.head: Artillery drill
div2.ab: —The Artillery Drill, off on the open plains, the movements by sound of the trumpet—
the battery of six guns,—the orders, "limber to the left" —the horses quickly attached, the trumpet blast for a signal and off they go.
The men attached to the guns
limber to the front, the bugle sounds, and off they go on a full run
The picturesque scene of a active battery drill on the open plain, the men at their positions, the signals orders, and signals by trumpet & off they go on a run
The pall cannons of pale yellow—the hurrying of horses, the ammunitions wagons, carrying an extra wheel behind , ̬some on their horses in the rear

div2.head: Antietam—the fight at the bridge. 17th Sept
div2.p:
This was a stone bridge over Antietam creek, in a position naturally
almost almost
impregnable and very strongly was fortified by the
rebels.
secesh
Orders were given to carry this point at all hazards, and the work was deputed to the 51st N.Y. and 51st Penn. The ch At 1 oclock these regiments made a charge with the bayonet, carrying the thing through with determination and courage never surpassed,— they cleared the bridge, gained the opposite side and held it—in the contest losing a very large number of officers and men

the 51st going on picket on the hill in advance
at the end on the
the day of Sunday 14th Dec battle field of Fredericksburgh after the fight engagement — They went on The fight general engagement was Saturday— 13th Sunday was comparatively quiet, with occassional picket firing and artillery firing. On Sunday night, the 51st was ordered, t
as an advance on a picket in force, to relieve the men in charge of holding a hill in advance of our line south of Fredericksburgh
some perhaps two miles beyond the river. The arrived at the 51st men went on this duty about 9 o'clock Sunday night. Any member of the regiment w who will remember recollect
till his dying day the circumstances of this night and the following day, till up to 12 o'clock Monday night—the regiment being on picket continuous duty—in a most dangerous position about 27 hours. The we They During the whole of that time, they every one, offi from the Colonel down was compelled to lie at full length on his back or belly in the mud, which was deep and tenacious. The pos surface of the ground near them slightly raised elevated
just south of them, served as a natural bulwark & protection against the rebel batteries and sharpshooters as long as the men lay in this manner: but the moment
the men raised their heads or a limb, even if only a few inches snap & s-s-st went the rebel weapons. of secesh In this manner, the 51st remained, spread out in the mud, all Sunday night, all Monday and Monday night till after midnight. but the rebels Although the troops could plainly hear the rebels whistling &c the latter did not dare to make a char advance upon them, although Altogether this was a most peculiar night to be remembered. About A Soon after midnight, the 51st was relieved, (as a blind) took up their march (the relief soon following) and through Fredericksburgh over the pontoon bridge, to Falmouth where they halted and took their old camp ground. Tuesday morning, 16th, about 3 3 oclock, after four wasteful days absence.
Papers! Papers!

At dusk dawn
Just after early candle light a horse man will come galloping through the camp, with something divinely white thrown across the pommel of the saddle in front of him; and you will hear the cry, papers! papers! There will then be Then quite a rush out of the tents, and the shinplasters fly around lively—the New York papers are 10 cents, and the Washington and Philadelphia one's 5.

div2.head: Falmouth, Tuesday morning Dec 23 '62
div2.p: I write this standing on the hill high slope between Gen. Sumner's head quarters and the railroad terminus down towards the river. The day is soft, brightly beautiful. Down below is spread out a picturesque scene. The countless baggage wagons, with their white roofs, the numerous strings of mules, the glis railroad locomotives, the broad spread stretch of slopes and hills— winding their way over the railroad track, and winding in ser an making a huge S from towards the river, which is only a few hundred yards distant, are the whole of the 51st N.Y. 51st Penn. and 100 men of the 11th N.H. going on picket duty along the shore

div2.head: Va. On the Falmouth side Falmouth Friday, Dec 26th '62
div2.p:
early this morning
I wandered
was saun
walked out, in the open fields, one side of the camp, I found some of the soldiers digging graves—they were for the 51st N.Y. and the 11th N.H. There was a
row of graves there already, each with a piece slat of board, generally a piece of barrel‑head, on which was inscribed the name of the soldier. Death is nothing here; as you step out in the morning from your tent to wash your face
a litt one side you see before you on a stretcher a a shapeless object, extended, shapeless
over which is and over it thrown a dark grey blanket—it is (the corpse of some wounded or sick soldier of the reg't some one who has died in the hospital tent during the night—perhaps there is a row of two or three three or four
of these
dead corpses lying covered over. No one minds them makes any ado. There is a detail of men made to bring them; all mere useless ceremony is omitted (The stern realities of the marches and many battles of a long campaign make all the old etiquets etiquettes a cumber and a nuisance.)

I walked on over amid to a camp of teamsters in the woods—or rather
what had been the woods, but was now pretty well cut down; a few trees standing at intervals, stumps all over and plenty of boughs and of branches strewing the ground. The men teamsters were in groups around, here and there, mostly squatted by the fires, idly, or cooking their breakfast, &c

Near by was the camp of the 26th Penn., who have been out since the commencement of the war. I entered into conversation talked with on
a group a couple of them the men , who had part of a squad collected around a fire, in an the usual enclosure of green branches, fenced fencing
around on two or three sides of a space perhaps 20 feet square; —breaks the wind from the north and east. Where there are boughs to be had These sylvan corrals are to be met with in all the camps when there are boughs to be had — —some of them are prepared built very finely, and give mak ing e a picturesque appearance
even for a camp. They serve as the company kitchens, and the same purposes of rendezvous, of an evening that the public house, the reading room, or the engine house did at home. (describe one of these sylvan corrals)

transpose.p: brigade consisting of 51st New York, 51st Penn and 21st Mass, (about 1800 men.)
*(see further on) at Leesboro Sept. 7th. joined by the 35th Mass. with 1000 men.

div2.p:
The men I talked with in the 26th Penn appeared to me to be in the best spirits and less desire to get growling, than any I had met with yet. To a stranger the men in the ranks appear great growlers. By & by you learn this is nothing; a larger proportion of men in the world, even the good fellows, would burst if they could not grumble The tents of these this
men camp were quite comfortable, such moderate weather as we are having now. One of the men came forward out of a tent close by with a couple of slices of beef, and some crackers, and commenced cooking the mess in a frying pan, for his breakfast . A —it looked very good. Another man was waiting with the same similar articles, to have the use of the frying pan. As I thorougly examined the little shelter tent through the raised open entrance, the ground strewn with pine twigs, and protected with on each side with a pine log for an entrance, the knapsacks piled at one end for pillows, (three men sleep in

head.hi: The tramp days fighting march on the bivouac

div2.p: After leaving Newport news for Falmouth (via Aquia creek) left Falmouth about 500 men Aug 12 ☜ * for Culpepper—now begins a most emphatic and experience being a continued life of rapid marching, on the bivouac, fighting, the sound of cannon, not hardly a single day intermitted for the best part of 100 days —15th Aug. at Cedar run— (the regiment now a part of Maj. Gen. Pope's army) 19th started in the retreat, to Kelly's ford , marching double quick most all the way—lay at Kelly's ford ford region two days—had a fight with the rebel Longstreet—23d left Kelly's ford, following the line of the Rappahannock, the rebels on the other side—24th at Sulphur Springs—left the springs next morning, and arrived at Warrenton the same day (25th) alarm of the enemy, line of battle formed, proved false report—marched to Warrenton Junction, arriving 26th laid there that day—27th started away but returned for Gainesville

transpose.p: one of these tents.) I thought, rough as it was, that men in health might endure it, and get along with more comfort than most f outsiders would suppose—as indeed the condition of the men around me was a tolerable proof.

The mass of men in the
our army are young—it is an impressive sight to me to see the countless numbers of youths and boys—there is only a sprinkling of elderly men On a regimental parade at evening there you see them,—poor lads, some many of them already with the experience of the oldest veterans.

div2.p: 28th started for Manassas, arriving there 29th. 30th and 31st were in engaged in the battle 2d Bull Run —the troops behaving with great coolness, courage and in perfect order—About 11 o'clock at night left the battle field, (being the last regiment that left and having the credit of saving the artillery) and bivouack'd that night at Centreville. Left the latter place Sept. 1st at 5 a.m. arriving at Chantilly at dusk—here occuring the a sharp engagement, (Battle of Chantilly) lasting till 10 o'clock at night. (It rained furiously, and the conflict was in the woods.) Sept. 2 at 3 a.m. started for Fairfax County House, arriving there soon after sunrise—2 p.m. for Alexandria, reaching the latter place at dark—Sept 3d in temporary camp at near Alexandria—4th at 8 p.m. started for Washington,—encamped at Park Garden in Washington at 3 a.m. on the 5th,

ab.seg: The greatest march that ever was made
Since the days of old King Pharoah
Was the march that was made by the 2d brigade

div2.p:
—lay there 5th and 6th—7th marched from Washington to Leesboro' Md., arriving there the same evening —8th laid there
a at Leesboro
>here joined by the 35th Mass. 1000 strong. 9th marched to Brookville 10th march'd to Damascus—11th and 12th on the march to Frederick city—13th to Middleton—14th engaged in the Battle of South Mountain (one of the fiercest fights of the war —15th march'd to S toward Sharpsburgh—16th ( and as all the past four days,) fighting shelling constant fusillades, and cam every hour on the alert and shelling the enemy) near Sharpsburgh, lying in lying till 17th, when the reg't was hotly engaged in the battle of Antietam , taking the bridge there at contest for the the point of the bayonet (in conjunction with the 51st Pa) and towards night rising a second time holding it against the violent efforts of the enemy to retake it see back 18 lay in the neighborhood, (no grub for two days,) expecting an attack from the enemy secesh , but they they now returned

two thousand
for scores and scores and hundreds and hundreds of miles

—all this two thousand miles through mud, rain, heat snow, cold, woods, bog, fording rivers, slipping down steep descents, rocks, climbing upright hills, exposed in the first part to heat the sweltering summer , in the last to severe changes, nipping and cool, over all strange routes, the amidst an active and
enemy, in secretiveness , way, the inhabitants full of treachery and venom, — the our men often marching without food, often worse, no water, the muddiest water sometimes a precious luxury, dragging their limbs, deadly tiresome, carrying heavy burdens, nature sometimes utterly exhausted, any moment liable to surprise, moving criss-cross to every point of the compass, and every cross-point, criss-cross hither and yon, now to escape from a superior enemy force , now to in pursuit to capture him, through gaps, footsore shoes worn out, feet bleeding, clothing torn, dirty not only sleeping on the ground in the open an and sometimes (that was nothing) having to (scrape away the snow to make a place to lie down .—fighting in some heavy historic battle one day, under at arms perhaps all night on the field, resuming the march next day, halting a little while on the bivouac at night and then with knapsacks on back and guns on shoulder again

19th encamped two miles distant, near mouth of Antietam creek—lay in camp there till Oct 7th at that date moved on to Pleasant Valley, Md., and lay there till the 27th & then struck tents, and crossed the Potomac on a ponton bridge at Berlin, marching to Lovettsville, Va. arriving there that night—30th marched near to Wheatland Va. ( And now commences another rapid
long march of of many days, bivouacking at night, fighting by day, every day hearing far or near the sound of cannon, generally but oftener near, than far. )—

2d Nov, started marched for Purcellville, encamping there that night (they were now following up with Gen. Pleasanton and his U.S. Calvary the movements of the rebel secesh cavalry under Gen Pleasanton
Stewart
Stuart ,) — 3d, on to Bloomfield,—4th on to Upperville—5th on over the Piedmont, and or abroad , encamping near Piedmont—6th and on the march (cold spiteful snowstorm,) near Orleans, Va.
—The chaplain—the doctor's (and the general account) of the incompentency of the chaplain,
the mail—
the letters in the adjudant tent—50 letters to be sent off, franked—going to all parts

div2.head: the doctor's statement
div2.p: When I went down the hill on Falmouth side , the and saw up the hills on the opposite side, the long rows of batteries, completely protected, we had to advance upon, I felt worse than whe later in the day, when in the hottest part of the fight.—The enemy had every advantage over us—we had to advance over a considerable open space, exposed to their batteries, and their infantry & sharpshooters protected by rifle-pits. Yet it was deliberately done. (I think there was as much bravery exhibited by our troops, in deliberate advancing, with perfect steadiness, and in their general conduct on Saturday, and steady holding the field on Sunday and Monday, as was ever exhibited by any military force in the world.— (Describe the slope on the Falmouth side—the bridge—the advance

p.transpose:
7th, lost the road, had to retrace ground, wandering away
several a number of miles, descending a steep very steep, rocky hill, sharp dangerous ledges of rocks, that night lays exhausted in the road and woods, in the snow
—8th started for Jeffersontown, arrived there at night, and bivouack'd, 9th (the enemy, under Pleasanton Stewart
had just left)—9th nothing new—10th no grub—11 on a reconnaissance, (no grub yet)—12th at 3 a.m. retired to Sulphur Springs—13th had crackers for the first time in several days—15th left Sulphur Springs at 7 a.m., when crossing the Rappahannock as soon as our artillery had moved gone the rebels secesh opened their guns on our baggage train, creating a panic among the teamsters—our artillery returned and silenced them—same day marched

div2.p: truth wounded in battle of Fredericksburgh between 6 and 7000 (in full)

to Fayettesville and bivouack'd— 15 16 th left camp at 7 a.m. and that night bivouack'd near Warrenton Junction— 16 17 th nothing new—18th started for Falmouth—19th encamped on the Rappahannock opposite Fredericksburgh—thus ending a march of 99 about 100 though not on a ground days, which, if properly narrated, would co stand on an equality par with any thing in military movements, ancient or modern.

Then —next comes the battle of Fredericksburgh, 13th—the 51st (as part of the ? 2d brigade, 2d division, 9th army corps, comprising besides at the 51st Penn, 21st Mass., 11th New Hampshire, & 35th Mass.) crossed the river on the 12th, advanced on the batteries of the 13th, the day of the battle, fought hotly and with unflinching courage, in the m
omit performing surgical operations on the battle field—Dr. Leonard at Fredericksburgh Saturday on the advance old vets , (i.e. veterans)
skeddadlers—some would skulk, of course, on their way to the fight—but not many

div2.p: out on a stretcher (in camp in front of a hospital tent) a dead man (\three dead men lying,\)\ each with a blanket spread over him—I lift it up one and look at the young dead man's face, so calm and yellow. 'tis strange!
How (Young man: I think this face of yours the face of the my dead Christ!)

div2.head: ? Dec. '62 Brigade drill Friday 26th
div2.p:
About 1 o'clock, there was a drill of the ? 2d Brigade, of the 2d division of the 9th Army Corps, comprising the 51st N.Y. Vol's, The 51st Penn, the 21st st Mass., (old regiments,) and the 35th Mass., and 11th N.H., under command of Brigadier General Ferrero. The Brigade turned out less than 1000 men—a significant commentary on war, for nearly every any one of its fine regiments originally started with more as many as that number, and besides there have been a good many recruits. What remain of the men, how
have the a though nearly all young fellows, have the look and gait of veterans. No show at all in the way of uniforms, but marching and evolutions perfect.

The drill closed with a spirited charge, the men shouting like wild Indians Comanches . I have been informed that the secession troops never utter these loud cries in their movements but are as stealth as cats. (This is an error—they do cry loudly in our charge. But our troops generally go in with loud cries.

The peculiar shriek of certain

The shouts and curses of men—

The wild cry on the of a regiment charging—(the

Sometimes the curious lull for a

div2.head: Christmas afternoon, 1862.
In Virginia, near the Rappahannock, Army of the Potomac
div2.p: I write this paragraph in the midst of a large deserted camp ground, with the remains of hundreds of mud-huts, and the dreb debris of an old brigade or division of soldiers all around me. On a road near at hand successive caravans some of them of army weapons apparently interminable each drawn with their six‑mule teams, are passing and passing with only slight intervals, nearly all the time. In the Not far off is a camp of several hundred teamsters with numerous rows and half‑moons of wagon, ranged in rows around— and heaps of forage, hay , temporary stables, &c. In sight as I sweep my eyes around over the open ground, (for I can see without obstruction for from two to four miles every way.) I see behold several other such teamsters' camps. Off outside I see the carcasses of dead masses and mules. The ground wooded parts of the surface have been cleaned, off for fuel, & building purposes, &c for two thous a hundred thousand soldiers

I hear plainly the music of a good band, at some Brigadiers quarters, a mile and a half away; for this it is a beautiful soft sunny Christmas day, with a thin haze in the air. There the drum tap or bugle sta from in one direction or other, comes constantly breaking in. Where I sit, I am not within two many several hundred rods of any soldiers' camp quarters — , but I can see them, regiments, brigades and divisions, spread out in the distance, at every point of the compass. All is open ground; not a particle of fence any where. Squads and of soldiers are wandering, crossing the space, the roads &c. at a distance;
opening life to the scene
but where I sit a couple of hundred feet of a road I am above all
around me quite solitary. . The effect is very pleasant and soothing. I am sitting on a remnant of pine log, the old groundsill
of a what was probably a large camp hut, a pine log . I can see to the south-east the depression in the landscape where the Rappahannock runs, and one or two signs of Fredericksburgh (which town a battery could easily shell it from where I sit.) I hear the sound of bugle calls, very martial, at this distance—a troop fine

lg.head: written by Mrs. Barbauld, in very old age
lg.l: Life! we've been long together.
Through pleasant and through cloudy weather.
'Tis hard to part when friends are dear.
Perhaps twill cost a sigh or tear:

l.seg: Then steal away—give little warning,
Choose thine own time,
Say not good night—but in some happier clime

lg.l: Bid me good morning

div2.head: The old flag of the 51st
div2.p: Old flag, all shot through with shell fragments of shell, and bullets &c its staff shattered, carried sternly through into seven general engagements and into the thickest of the fight and safely brought out again—all full of shreds, fringed as with the sword, its silk stained with blood

large troop of cavalry is just passing, the hoofs of the horses shake the ground, and I hear the clatter of sabres Amid all this pleasant scene, under the delic sweet sky and warm sun, I sit
muse sit and think of over the battle, of last Saturday week.
Taking the army as a whole, it is almost certain that never did man mortal man in an aggregate fight better than our troops at Fredericksburgh

In a
one the highest sense, just as great as it was no failure . The main body troops on Friday, descending the hills on the Falmouth side, to cross the pontoon bridges, could plainly see the over beyond back of Fredericksburgh, the rebel secesh batteries rising in tremendous force and plenty, on the ridges terraces of to reach which required to our men crossing cros sing exposed stretches of land, which were swept fearfully commanded by the batteries, and were also the flats thick with their rifle pits. This was what they had something to confront and our men yet they all the brigades went forward unflinchingly, nearer view on Saturday, the day of the fight, made the case every thing still
more ominous to our side. But still the men advanced with unsurpassed gallantry—and would have gone still again
* further if ordered.

div2.head: The comic side of death
div2.p: Death of a middle-aged man, (Joshua Ford) he belonged to co. E. 1st Delaware regt.) in one of the hospitals Jan 13th '63. He occupied bed 31, ward G. campbell hosp seemed to be perfectly conscious. —he had a good-natured attentive nurse who never wearied of well-doing— —he wanted plug tobacco—he said to the nurse every few minutes during the night, "Now give another plug of tobacco—I'm going to die soon." He had plenty of rum and water, by order of the physician. He said, would often say "Now give me some more toddy"—He wished some person would come in liked company— —he was quite curious—did not seem to mind death at all—took it very phlegmatically—( occ —spoke of it with perfect coolness.)—was a widower—died towards morning without pain—one of his the last things was taking a drink of rum & water

p.add:
Instead of two regiments in the field, from Brooklyn, there are eight, as follows:
Fifth Artillery, Col. Graham, at Baltimore.
Thirteenth, Col. Clark, in Virginia. (three months.)
Fourteenth, Lieut. Col. Fowler, in Virginia.
Sixty-seventh, Col. Adams, in Virginia.
Eighty-seventh, Col. Dodge, in Virginia.
Forty-seventh, Col. Moore, in South Carolina.
Forty-eighth, Col. Perry, (deceased) in Georgia.
Ninetieth, Col. Morgan, Key West. And in addition to the above, as the records of the Relief Commission will show, Brooklyn men have contributed largely, in somes cases in entire companies, to fill up New York city regiments, which are now at the seat of war. There were no Irish or German regiments, as such, from Brooklyn, but it is well known that these nationalities are strongly represented in the army; and Brooklyn Germans and Brooklyn Irishmen will be found by companies, sufficient to fill two regiments in Meagher's and Blenker's brigades.
